A coaster to help keep your table dry.

Strips:
The trickiest part of building and assembling this item is the strips used for the weave.
You will need to print 14 strips, 7 of each colour if you want the check effect.
I recommend you print the strips with a single perimeter to allow greater flexibility and fairly close to the bed to get a good bonding.
When printed make sure the plugs on the ends of the strip are clear of unwanted plastic, which does sometimes accumulate when using my printer at least.
There is a knack to fitting the strips onto the base, you need to guide the inner side of the plug into the hole first, then roll back onto the other side to clip it in, see photo. sometimes this requires some force.
If one or two of the plugs do not lock do not worry, when you put the frame on these will be held down just the same.
Frame:
Be careful when removing the frame from the print bed as you do not want to bent it. I recommend pulling it up vertically by one corner quickly, this seem to snap it off the bed with no bending.
Base:
When fitting the fully populated base into the frame you may have to bend it slightly for the last two corners, this is not a problem as long as you do not loosen the strips.
Good luck, I hope you enjoy making this.

title: 1" Webbing to Arkiv Rail Adaptor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I have 2 pieces of gear that are part of my EDC my R6 rucksack and a pouch from Fabric Horse. I wanted to mount the pouch to the R6 so I made this adapter. You feed any thin 1" nylon webbing through the H portion on the back of the adapter, the other side mounts to the Arkiv rail on the R6. This method of mounting the webbing is convenient since the webbing and buckle do not need to be sewn in place, you just place the buckle on the pre-sewn webbing loop. The buckles are fully removable.

Infill is 80% with 2 shells, layer height of .27mm, feed rate 55 extruding, 90 travel.
filament was maker brand Acid Lake 1.8mm, prints like a dream
extruder temp was 235C, platform temp 110C
print with supports, make sure long axis of the base of the buckle is parallel with the sides of the build platform. If it is perpendicular to the sides the left portion of the buckle tends to lift up and warp at least on our Replicator 1.

One of my homemade CNC machines. This is a relatively cheap version. The linear guides consists of 608zz bearings and plumbing pipe NEW version available here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659021

BOM:
Plumbing pipe Â½" 21,3mm outside diameter:
2x550mm
2x270mm
2x776mm 42x 608ZZ bearings
12x 1Â½" U-bolts (see picture)
2 metres of 8mm threaded rod
6x M8 long nuts (coupling nut for assembling two rods)
32x M6x50mm bolts
32x M6 (10mm diameter, 20mm in length) furniture assembly nuts (see picture)
24x M8X16mm bolts
24x M8 Nuts
Aluminium angle 20x20mm 1.5mm thickness
Around 2m M5 threaded rod for mounting the steppers and the dremel
52x M5 nuts
16x M5 spacers
Rubber fuelhose with inner diameter of 5-6mm for holding the dremel and for steppercouplings. 22mm MDF - for all the parts Electronics:
3 Nema 23 steppers
Any stepper driverboard ( i can recommend those from http://cnc4you.co.uk/ or gecko G540)
Power supply according to the driverboard and stepper specifications
And of course, a Dremel more parts to come... In this version i have used a cheap china stepper driver board from ebay. I can only say that you get what you pay for! It is possible to get it to work with the cheap boards, but you have to go really slow to avoid missing steps. They are not designed very good, and tweaks found on the net does not make them much better. I have used Gecko G540 with great succes, it is a superb board. But also a breakoutboard combined with the cheap stepper drivers from the link in the BOM does a great job like the Gecko. Software used for running the machine:
Mach3
Linux EMC2 CAM program used:
Lazycam Unfortunately i only have a very poor video of the machine in action. I have sold it, so i can't make a new video. The video is played at played at 4 times original speed.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MEzmb7wuGx0 The thing is marked as work in progress as i will continue to fill out the BOM and also write some instructions if anyone is showing interest in this.

A servo controlled arm robot I made after seeing some nice servos on Aliexpress. The Arm has four servos and the gripper has one small plastic servo. The robot is controlled by an Arduino Uno mounted on a base plate hidden in the robot base. This was a very fun project to make.
See video: http://youtu.be/kxjjVPYn-dg?list=UU2xIrj2i0tUdzQWHZC987zw

I got the idea to make this robotic arm after seeing these servos on AliExpress.
http://www.aliexpress.com/snapshot/6109088089.html
After I had ordered the servos I made a 3D model of them from the drawing on their web page and then started to design the robot parts with 3D printing in mind. I had no 3D printer at the time so it was all very theoretical. I use Rhino 3D by the way. Finally my servos arrived and I also got my Flashforge Creator X.
The base for the robot is too big for the 3D printer platform so I had to slice it up in 3 parts. I used ABS with 10% infill on all part except for the base tower (top part) that I wanted a bit sturdier, so I used 25% infill for that. When printed, I chemically welded the parts with ABS dissolved in Acetone (the yellow stuff in the glass jar in the video).
I also made a little base plate for the Arduino Uno so it could be hidden nicely in the base.
When the arm was done and tested I started to make the gripper. It is using a small almost free little 9g plastic servo and hence it is not very strong. I also realized that if closing it around an object forcing the servo to try to reach its zero position, it easily breaks (plastic gears get stripped out). With that in mind I added a micro switch that senses when the gripper has closed around an object and tells the Arduino to stop turning the servo (see pictures). Maybe one could improve the construction with flexible (rubber bands?) grippers or something. Any ideas are welcome.
All in all, I am pretty happy about how it turned out, it was fun to make and has just cost me around $60 in parts and a third of a spool of filament.
I you make one, please please post pictures and videos of it! I would love to see how yours turn out :)

I am the CAD designer for FIRST team TNT (3840) This is an archive of all the CAD parts I designed for my FRC team during the 2014 build season except the adjustable camera mount, which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248033. Despite the better grip of Camiel's Hobbed Shaft, with respect to the Orca v3 pulley, I still experience slippery filament. So a rep rapper advised me to go and use the MK8 gear. Unfortunately that comes with a 5mm bore, while all my configuration used m4 bolts and bearings. So I modified JackT's extruder derivate, to fit my original bearings but have the MK8 in the middle. This means, different holes for the filament and different holes to mount all to the baseplate. Still w.i.p. so don't print yet. Other components yet to come.

  • Please 'LIKE' before collecting!
    Thomas www.3daybreaker.blogspot.com

Update 2014-08-04: First prints need minor adjustments. Holes for mounting are not exactly above each other and idler does not touch filament. Version 2 is in design mode. Update 2014-08-06: Bottom piece redesigned with aligning holes and more idler space. Be advised, if you don't already have JackT's extruder, get the OTHER components from HIS thing! Print the 2 parts with 40% infill and solid layer every 15th. The "TOP" piece needs support on my printer. Locate the bottom piece over the hot end, align with a piece of filament straight into the hot end. Mark and and drill new holes in base plate Mount top piece on bottom piece with original bolts and reassemble the idler section with new bolt, bearings and washers. You'll need some additional hardware: Bearings 13mm with bore 5mm: http://nl.aliexpress.com/item/10Pcs-695Z-5mm-x-13mm-x-4mm-Miniature-Deep-Groove-Radial-Ball-Bearings/1750603536.html A 5mm bolt length 64 to 65 mm a lot of 9mm washers with 5mm bore A self sealing hex nut 5mm
Noticed a lot of people having an issue with the broken .stl file. Went ahead and repaired it. With a layer height of 0.14mm slicing took about 5 minutes but exportation took about 45 minutes.

This linear bearing consists of 5 races, which are printed separately. Each race contains 18 (copper) balls of 3.2 mm. I got the balls from the Dutch "Huis en Comfort" site: http://www.huis-en-comfort.nl/Glasreiniger-kogeltjes-480899.html?group=765764. If you want to use a bit larger diameter tube, you only have to design the outer housing yourself (the pentagon-like thing) and make it a bit larger. The races will fit in the corners and give a nice smooth run. Have Fun!

The ball channel is only 0.4 mm larger than the actual ball size. As you can imagine, you need a nice smooth print. So make sure that your printer is properly calibrated and does not use too much plastic. Too little is better than too much in this case!  
I printed my races with a 10% decrease in flow compared to normal (calibrated) operation.

comments.text: Very nice. I was thinking to build a ball spline, using a square shaft, and such balls recirculating system. Do you think it should be strong enough to drive an extruder (direct drive) like the one I started to design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:398324)?
comments.author: fma

comments.text: Hey there, very original system you have there! If I understand correctly you want to use a ball spline to drive your main gear, which drives the extruder, right? I think it can exert enough pressure, the only disadvantage I can think of is that if you apply too much pressure, the balls will be pushed in their bearing "seats" and it will "clamp up" the rod hindering linear movement.
Yes, you're right... Any idea of the max load we can use on the balls, before they 'clamp up'?
comments.author: Alphie

comments.text: I don't really know, but I guess there is only one way to find out! :) Maybe if you take a bit wider square tube that you can decrease the clamping effect.
Brilliant!

description.text: WOHOO

Simple Useless-Machine-upgrade to Torsten's Arduino Uno case, using a mini servo, an Arduino Uno and a switch.
Easy to build!
In action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oNcqNcCd2UA&feature=youtu.be

• an Arduino Uno board
  • a mini servo (width: 12 mm, length: 23 mm)
  • a switch (diameter: 6.2 mm)
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28971

    Step 1: Print both parts and the Arduino Uno case (if the normal case doesn't print properly on your printer, try the 0.3mm or 0.4mm gap version)
    Step 2: Attach the lever to the servo
    Step 3: Mount the servo on the case
    Step 4: Assemble the switch
    Step 5: Wire your Useless Machine:
    Step 6: Upload the example programm or your own to the Arduino
    Step 7: Nothing, you're done! Please upload a photo ;)

    Wiring:

  • Connect the black/brown servo wire to the ground of your Arduino
  • Connect the red servo wire to the 5V pin of your Arduino
  • Connect the white/yellow servo wire to pin 9
  • Connect one side of the switch to pin 10
  • Connect the other side of the switch to the ground
    (switch should be open when it's pointing in the direction of the flap)

description.text: Latest in my line of baby gate accessories, apparently: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3768 The square steel tube of the Evenflo baby gate smack against a painted wooden cabinet. This thing snaps onto the square tubes solidly and provides a nice buffer to hopefully keep from damaging the cabinet. FYI, I designed and built a different version that snapped on and worked great, but it occurred to me it was a choking hazard if my daughter happened to pry it off. I redesigned the part using the "can't fit in a toilet paper tube" criteria, so it ends up being 40mm wide.
Notice there are three tiny tabs inside the hook. With the tabs in place, it's designed to be too tight to fit. To get a nice snug fit, sand or file these down til the part snaps right on.
Crocodile

Here is man's best friend, ready for printing.
The model shown was printed on a 5th Generation Replicator in white PLA. Then it was finished using bronze mettalic paint.

This scan was made using a Next Engine scanner and then refined in Sculptris, Meshlab and Mesh Mixer.
The file was left fairly large to include as much detail as possible.

comments.text: What controller did you use?
comments.author: sailorbob134280

comments.text:
Hi. For this particular CNC I used a cheap chinese board with parallel port from ebay. It was about 50$ with integrated drivers. But I would recommend to use a better controller.
For my next CNC I have made a DIY board (http://www.planet-cnc.com/index.php?page=diy)http://www.planet-cnc.com/inde.... This is a breakoutboard with USB support. It will also require a driver for each stepper.
For another low cost CNC I have used a GRBL type of controller. This is just an arduino uno with a shield on top. On the shield there are a couple of drivers to run the steppers. The arduino is a cheap solution and also gives USB support instead of the outdated parallel port.

author: Bror

description.text:
This set of files is for the Nova Labs High Altitude Rocket Project (HARP) with a goal of launching a low orbital altitude rocket with an on board FPV video and autonomous navigation back to the launch site. The outcome will be to have video footage throughout the flight as well as telemetry. We are hoping (and have requested) the support of NARHAMS and others to assist us. We will test each version when we go to NASA Goddard, scaling up as necessary.
Update: Added some interesting scaled up fin cans
Update 8/27/14: NASA recently published a series of 3D models which included the Jupiter C. I imported it and modified it to be a flyable model rocket. We are going to do a test flight to see if the lower half is suitable for flight as is and if so then scale it up to hold 4 engines and act as a Stage 1 and Stage 2 of HARP. It's not perfect and can use some cleanup but that's what tinkering is all about. Update: I thought you would like to know that all rockets flew successfully (except for HARP 3, because it was too heavy). The Jupiter C absolutely needs a C class engine and HARP 1 easily hit 700ft on a C6-5.

title: Raspberry Pi camera case/enclosure (remeshed for low vertex count)

description.text: This is just a lower poly count version of VGer's awesome case (thing:92208). The bottom is a lower poly version of thing:158664, one of the former object's derivatives. I had trouble when I tried to print these parts - it even crashed repetier-host, a first for me!

I ran both parts Meshlab's quadratic edge collapse decimation filter (set to 50%) a few times, I was able to get it down significantly! The top part I got down to 556 vertices (from 37K), and the bottom part down to just 1212 vertices (from 38K). Basically I kept hitting apply until the vertices were way low and the model still had all the detail. Turning on the wireframe let me see that there was a whole lot of vertices in the model that were not really going to make it look any better when I printed it on my somewhat rough-around-the-edges printr ;)
Printed great on my Printrbot using Repetier Host and Slicr. Hopefully it works for you!

This is a small case I made for the the GPS receiver base on a Ublox NEO-6M, as shipped by Unmanned Tech in the UK.

Update 11/08/2014: Added a bit more space around the parts to allow for slight over-printing problems stopping the lid from attaching. Added an option to create four holes in the base to allow for fixing to a quad. There is now also a configurable parameter tolerance, which is a distance that will be added between the lid and the base, and between the base and the PCB. The default is set pretty tight.
The latest snapshot is available on GitHub.
This is a small case I made for the the GPS receiver base on a Ublox NEO-6M, as shipped by Unmanned Tech in the UK.

Update 11/08/2014: Added a bit more space around the parts to allow for slight over-printing problems stopping the lid from attaching. Added an option to create four holes in the base to allow for fixing to a quad. There is now also a configurable parameter tolerance, which is a distance that will be added between the lid and the base, and between the base and the PCB. The default is set pretty tight.
The latest snapshot is available on GitHub.

Print out the two parts that comprise the base and the lid. The defaults should be fine for a v2 GPS module, although the tolerances are set very tight.
Either using the Configurator here, or by editing the scad file, you can easily change the following settings:
  • GpsBase The width of the GPS PCB. Assumed to be square, if yours isn't, put the longest dimension.
  • UnderDepth and OverDepth The clearance required below and above the PCB for components.
  • CableHoleW The width of the hole for the cable.
  • CableHolePos How far from the edge is the cable connector?
  • MountingCentres The distance between the mounting holes to make in the base. Set to zero to not make any holes.
  • MountingBoltSize The diameter of the mounting holes.
  • Thickness How thick to make the walls, floor and lid.
  • Shelf How wide to make the shelf that the PCB sits on. Probably only need to change this if you have some components particularly close to the edge of the PCB.
  • CornerRadius How curved to make the box.
  • PCB The thickness of the PCB.
  • Window The diameter of the hole in the lid for the GPS signals to go through. Set to zero for no hole.
  • Tolerance The extra space to add between the lid and base, and between the PCB and the walls.

Print standing straight up with a raft and supports and it comes out very nice.

This is a shell for the Turbo Everdrive flash cartridge for the TurboGrafx-16. I recently picked one of these carts up from Stone Age Gamer, and couldn't justify spending an extra $40 for a small piece of acrylic to cover the top. It looks pretty naked in the TG16 without a shell though, so I made this. It has text built into the model, so it doesn't need a label. It has cutouts so you can access the PCE/TG16 switch and uSD slot, and has a small lever to press the reset button. The bottom is formed to rest on the PCB and chips, so it has a solid feel to it.
Simply print, press through the mounting holes, then use something to melt the plastic in the hole to hold it in place (I used an old soldering iron tip). Attached is the STL file as I printed it, as well as the Sketchup design files. One is in the final form, and the other has the text still seperate, so it can easily be changed/removed (in case you want to label it with a sticker or something). UPDATE: I recently got a dual extruder printer, so I decided to print the text in a different color to make it stand out a bit more. I think it came out looking pretty good (it was yellow ABS filament, but looks kinda green). I also added a small hole for the LED to shine through, and a couple other minor tweaks.

I printed this in black ABS.  I used my normal settings, except I changed the number of horizontal shells to one (down from three), so the text outlines looked cleaner.  
Once printed, I pressed the pegs through the mounting holes, which protrude a little bit beyond the board.  I melted the plastic pegs flush with an old soldering iron tip by pushing them down into the hole, which firmly attached the shell to the board.  
Fresh from the printer, I found the text to be a little bit difficult to read, since the plastic is so shiny.  So I roughed up the surface with a little bit of 220 grit sandpaper to give the top a matte finish, which made the text much more readable.  You could also use a bit of paint to give the lettering some color... or you could just remove the lettering and add a printed label.  
Update: I printed this with my new dual extruder printer using yellow ABS for the lettering.  Rather than creating a seperate STL file for the color, I simply set the printer to create support material from the other extruder (since the lettering in the model is all recessed, support will fill the gap underneath it).  I tweaked the support material settings to make it fully fill the grooves, rather than making an easily removable sparse support.

remixed_from.author: tonyyoungblood
remixed_from.title: Ultimate Samsung Galaxy Note 3 Case w/ Cover, Magnetized, Sugru

description.text:
Here's a no-frills variation of my Ultimate Note 3 case. This version ditches the cover, magnets and Sugru bumpers.
.
Here are the other variations:
  • Ultimate (Magnets, Cover, Bumpers):
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:407517
  • No Bumpers (Magnets, Cover):
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:414865
  • No Cover (Sugru Bumpers, No Magnets):
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:424089
    .
    I designed the case in two parts so that printers with small build areas (6"x6") such as the Printrbot Simple Metal could still print it.
    .
    This case is designed to fit the Note 3 WITHOUT the original back piece. You can still access the battery by sliding off the two sections.

• Print the Top and Bottom using support structures. I highly recommend InTheGarage's Slic3r settings here: http://www.camwatt.com/printrbot-simple-metal-slic3r-settings.html
    .
  • Clean out the support structures using pliers. Fine tune with a Dremel and sandpaper. Be very careful around the openings. Keep testing until you achieve a snug fit. (Remove Note 3 back before sliding on case. This case doesn't use the original back.) I added a half millimeter extra of length to the edges where the Top and Bottom meet in order to get a gapless fit. You may need to sand these areas to achieve a perfect fit.
    .
  • Remove the Note 3's original back piece and slide the case right over the exposed back. This case does not use the original back. You can easily access the battery and sd card by sliding off your new case's top and bottom.
    .
    Enjoy the case! Let me know if you have any suggestions for improvement.

Stuff some aluminum foil in the top of the rocket, and it should ignite the bottle rocket if you make a small hole in the aluminum foil.

title: Steampunk Goggle Hex Head Bolt Remix

description.text: Fake hex head bolts for DAstronomer's Steampunk Goggles.

It's been a while since I made this but I think I did it with abs, 0.2mm layer (supports on the head file). I don't remember how many shells but I think 1 shell at 100% would be a good place to start. Maybe 2 shells if your not going to print it at 100%. Print the pin on its side (one of the flat sides). Removed the support and solvent welded the head to the pin. The "nut" should just friction fit because it's tight. I printed all the heads/nuts in one print and all the pins in another print but I don't think it really matters. Just make sure you have enough pieces on the build platform so each layer has time to cool sufficiently since they will print rather quickly. Seems like I had to drill out the holes a little on the glasses but that may have just been because I spay painted them first.  
The elastic band is from a cheap face shield I bought at harbor freight. It was pretty cool how it matched my paint scheme perfectly. I did have to resize the strap buckles to get them to fit the width of the elastic band properly.   
Hope it works out well for you!

description.text:
A two part spool for holding smaller (0.25lb) quantities of filament. 16cm outer diameter, with a 3.5cm opening in the center. Each half threads together.
The thread on the larger part is standard 50x5 thread, while the smaller section was modified to have an additional 0.8mm of clearance to ensure they still fit together regardless of printer tolerance.

Note: The threads are 'pointer' than I would really like, so depending on material/cooling/layer height, you might find the pointiest bit wants to peel away. You can either ignore it, and just screw the halves together and keep it hidden, or pull of the any non-adhering filament and clean it up with sandpaper.  
You will need to flip one of the halves to print properly. If I get time I'll try and re-upload a fixed STL.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2BpokDErPyl

The Earth Globe 360x is flooded with oceans 360 meters deeper than yesteryear. The Earth is an Oblate Spheroid in this sculpture based on the ETOPO2 database. The Ice Caps were left intact, to accurately illustrate the volume of ice versus the volume of mountains. It is an accurate analog based on digital elevation models.
This 3D model has 6 Megabytes of data for 120,000 triangles. The Amazon Basin is under water, The Mississippi Valley is submerged. And worse...

The oblateness uses 0.64 as the factor which multiplies the globe z axis values.
ETOPO2 Notes:
Land topography is from the GLOBE Project, an internationally designed, developed, and independently peer-reviewed global digital elevation model (DEM), at a latitude-longitude grid spacing of 30 arc-seconds (30"). The GLOBE Task Team was established by the Committee on Earth Observation Satellites (CEOS). It is part of Focus I of the International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme - Data and Information System. Primary contributors to the GLOBE database are: (Click here for more details online.)
National Imagery and Mapping Agency (formerly Defense Mapping Agency), Fairfax, Virginia, USA
Geographical Survey Institute, Tsukuba, Japan
Australian Surveying and Land Information Group, Canberra, ACT, Australia
Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, California, USA
University College London, UK
DLR-German Remote Sensing Data Center, Oberpfaffenhofen, Germany
NOAA National Geophysical Data Center, Boulder, Colorado, USA
USGS EROS Data Center, Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA Data Base Assembly
The five major data sources were assembled into the single ETOPO2 2-minute data base without formal edge matching or other methods that alter the data as initially posted. Higher-resolution data take precedence: data derived from GLOBE mask all other data, Smith/Sandwell data come next, followed by IBCAO, with the 5-minute data filling any gaps. Five-minute data from DBDBV and ETOPO5 and 30-second data from GLOBE were regridded to 2 minute spacing by bicubic spline interpolation. IBCAO data were originally gridded in a polar stereographic projection; these data were interpolated along lines of constant latitude at 2 minute steps for every 2 minutes of latitude from 72° North to the pole.

I keep tennis balls on my desk at work to juggle and to practice my serve toss during breaks. The loose balls look out of place on my desk, so I made this stand to make them look better on my desk and to keep them from rolling off my desk.

I modeled the stand in Rhino 5.
I printed the stand on a Makerbot Replicator 2 in low 300 micron resolution with 2 layers and 10% infill and no raft or supports. I used a PRINTinZ printer plate, which has been working great and saving me time and money, because I don't need to use rafts or tape for most prints any more.

title: MakerGear StepStruder wire clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a clip that snaps to the gearbox of a MakerGear stepper motor extruder and holds the wires from your hot end to keep them from hitting your X-axis belt and from flexing as your x-axis moves.
It was designed parameticly in openSCAD, so you can edit the size of the clip to hold differnet sized wires or clip to different sized cylendars. 
I use it with a single wire clip, but you can have 2 or 3 ( or more, edit the SCAD file!) if you need them.

Print it on a 3D printer. I use two of them (one "left" and one "right") to fully capture the wire, but a single thick one may work for you. See the photo for how it works.  I updated the 1-clip_thick stl file to use a 34mm diameter instead of the actual measured MG gearbox size of 35mm. It snaps over and holds a bit tigher.

-PRINT IN CURA FOR SLICING CAPABILITIES
-PRINT AT .75 SCALE FOR NEAR ACTUAL GAME SIZE
There are three types of files you can download depending on your preferred way to build this model.
-The first is: NO-E files. recognized by the "NO-E" at the end of the file, NO-E files are files designed specifically for a basic model with no electronics(hence the name: NO-E). This will be good for anyone that may have doubt in their soldering/electrical skills or just someone who doesn't want a Ghost that lights up.
-The second type is: E files. signified by the "E" at the end of the files name, E files are designed to add electronics into your model. such things as LED's, speakers, and/or microphones (or anything else really) along with knowledge of soldering and electricity will be needed to finish this model. This is good for the more advanced builders out there that want their ghost to light up or say things.
-the third type of file has no ending to it and these files can be used for both of the builds.
So What Do I Download?
download whichever set of files seem to interest you the most. However, for ANY build you will need to download all general files ALONG with your set of preferenced files so that your builds are complete. Special Edition (red & white ghost)- you will need a back and a front Regular (white ghost)- you will need two backs
DETAILED INSTRUCTIONS WILL BE ADDED SOON

comments.text: It sounds like your print came off the bed during the print. A way you can solve this is by putting stick glue on the bed if it's glass or blue painters tape if the bed is any other material. Also I would not recommend to use those settings. Printing at 200-300 microns is completely fine. Also infill is perfectly fine at 15-25%. Also, since you are having problems with it sticking to the bed and to layers, use a brim in your software and maybe increase the nozzle temp just a bit. I hope this helps

title: Spool Holder for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
I have an updated version here...
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:510696 I wanted a simple spool holder that fit these 4 requirements:
Required no extra parts after printing
Required no support material during the print.
Mounted securely above the Printrbot
Rotates vertically to feed the filament (working with gravity), minimizing strain on the extruder gears.
Well, I couldn't find one like that, so I made my own!

No support material is needed!
There are four main parts, the holder, the bar, the bar-cap, and the spacers. You can always use a piece of PVC pipe for the bar if you want to save on plastic. I'd also recommend printing a pair of spacers, depending on the size of your spool.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:418822

comments.text: Would it be possible to hold two 1kg spools side by side with this design or would that make it unbalanced?

author: OverrideStudios

description.text:
Is your MK4 sitting unused and lonely since you\'ve upgraded to the MK5? Give it a new lease on life and turn it into a handheld welding gun! Use it to patch up any holes or loose threads in your prints or to glue broken plastic parts back together. You can see me welding the lid of a very poorly printed and particularly dangerous teapot shut to prevent accidental use.
The STL files include parts for a hand grip that slips over the DC motor, a finger guard so you don\'t burn yourself on the retainer washer, and a trigger bracket for a push button. SolidWorks 2010 model files are also included.

Assembly Instructions:
  • Print out the hand grip, finger guard, and trigger bracket.
  • Glue the finger guard into the slot in the hand grip flush with the bottom of the grip.
  • Separate the DC motor wires with the black wire towards the back and red wire towards the front.
  • Slip the hand grip over the DC motor with the black wire in between the slot in the back and the red wire through the slot in the front.
  • Secure the hand grip to the motor using an M3x15 screw and M3 nut. Do not over-tighten the nut otherwise the tabs may crack.
  • Insert a 1/4 in. push button through the hole in the trigger guard.
  • Solder the red wire of the motor to one of the poles on the push button. Solder another length of wire to the other pole of the button. This will be connected to terminal 1A (+) on the extruder controller.
  • Glue the trigger bracket onto the finger guard.
  • Connect the black motor wire to terminal 1B (-) on the extruder controller.
  • Connect the thermistor and heater wires to the extruder controller. You may need to lengthen the wires if you are connecting to an extruder controller mounted on/in your makerbot. If you have a spare extruder controller you can mount it directly to the MK4 and connect to the motherboard using a CAT5 cable, making it much more portable and interchangeable.
    • Usage: Open up the control panel in ReplicatorG and set the temperature to 220C. When the nozzle is at the right temperature, set the motor PWM to 255 and select \'forward\'. The motor will not turn until you push the trigger button, allowing you to control the extrusion manually. Be careful not to operate the motor until the nozzle is fully heated up, otherwise the filament may strip or the nozzle may break!

comments.author: Keavon

comments.text: I think welding things together using the same material is always better than using an adhesive, that way the joint has the same mechanical properties as the structural material, like stiffness, melting temperature, etc. Welding with ABS also allows you to sand off any excess material without affecting the finish of the model. Hot glue is much more flexible, has a lower melting point, and can't be sanded easily. It's also fairly easy to peel apart things glued using hot glue.

title: UP! Plus / Afina Heated Build Chamber

description.text:
This is a Work In Progress.  It was a built in kind of a rush, so I'll be uploading more details when I can.  The temps in the office fell to below 50F after the heater broke.  The builds were de-laminating and generally poor quality.  The heated build chamber tends to maintain at about 50C and all my prints since then have been great!  This is the best quality I've ever gotten and not a hint of warping.  I'm worried about cooling for the motor and extruder and will be hooking up an air pump to the extruder shortly.  
I used a small heater I picked up from the thrift store to heat the chamber.  It's called the "Worlds Smallest Big Heater" from the Sharper Image and it works great.  I Imagine the extruder and the platform would heat up the chamber if you didn't have a heater, but I liked having the option.  So far it has worked wonderfully well.  I have the heater on an outlet timer to turn it off after a while, if prints are left un-attended or I forget.  It has a high and low setting.  I've been using High and get about 50C build chamber temps.
I've left the base of the printer out of the chamber because that's where all it's brains are.  There is a slot on the top of the chamber where the filament feeder tube runs.  The spool mount is bolted on to a piece of ply above the rear of the printer.  It would have worked better to use the usual mount, but I moved the location of the printer which made the usual mounting location un-usable.
The front and right sides are doors.  After using this for a while I am very glad I made them as big as I did.  I'm also glad I left extra clearance space all around, especially vertically.  This is very helpful when working on the extruder.  If you were building one, I'd put a third door on the other side as well, but I ran out of plastic in the scrap pile.  The doors are acrylic and I think the sides are either acrylic or polycarb  (thin sheet).
I made a custom build platform which is wider than the stock UP! build platform to accommodate the bulldog clips which could be struck by by the extruder during large prints before the modification.
The actual build tray is GRP which has been scratched up with a knife.  I'd like to use the CNC to make a better looking tray but this seems to work well enough for now.  I've never had a print raft lift from the platform after I started spreading a thin mixture of ABS dissolved in acetone over the build tray every 10 prints or so, or after I clean the tray.  
I've uploaded my Wall Thickness Tester stl because I was required to upload something not an image.  The thicknesses start at 0.1mm and go up by 0.1mm incrementally.

Dimensions are coming, but mostly I just wanted to add another thought to the collection of build chambers out there and perhaps help those who are considering building one.
The doors are held close with magnets.  The door hinges are small strips of fiber-tape that has been doubled over and screwed in under the side panes.  This is easy, cheap, and seems to work really well, especially compared to installing actual hinges.  If you were going to use hinges, I'd recommend printing some with flat surfaces that you could glue to the acrylic.  Another thought was model airplane control surface hinges, but the tape seems to be working well.

author: benglish

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117519 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=117519

Using the following options: Text_Rotate = 0
Text_Font = write/orbitron.dxf
Text_Size = 5
Your_Text = Matt bounds

Filament Guide for the Makerbot Replicator (Dual)
The guide keeps the two filaments sufficiently away from the rear wall of the Replicator. The filaments are thus pulled up from the reels, instead of at an angle to prevent the filament from tangling betwen the reel and the wall. This is especially noticeable on the reel for the left extruder: the filament can become loose, and because of the "large" distance between the reel and the wall, it will roll between the reel and the wall, becoming a huge tangle.
This guide was designed for the Replicator (Dual). It might work with a single extuder Replicator but a) I don't know if it's even necessary if the reel is close to the wall (like the right extruder reel in the Dual) and b) if it is indeed useful, it might not be as stable since it only attaches to one of the filament tubes.
Version 2 of the Guide is a bit more robust, but otherwise it does the same and is printed the same way.

Printing instructions
You need to make sure that the first layer you print sticks well to the print bed, otherwise the bottom circular guides will come out looking badly. I printed this using ABS.
  • 0.2 mm layers
  • enable support ('doRaft' = true)
    Installation on the Replicator (Dual)
    The guide attaches to the filament tubes that are attached to the rear wall via the plastic clamps.
  • Unclamp the two tubes.
  • Slide the whole guide behind the thick power cable
  • Slide the top circular guides onto the filament tubes from the top until they reach the bottom of the circular guides. They should fit snuggly. Re-attach the filament tubes to the rear wall with the clamps.
  • Snap the filaments into the bottom circular guides though the vertical slits

description.text: This is a lamp shade designed to work with Ikea's Hemma Cordset. See the instructions for important information about how to print this thing. If you are printing with PLA, then the absolute maximum amount of power lightbulb you can use is around 10-15 watts. This limits you to high-efficiency LED bulbs of around 500-800 lumens. Many CFLs may be too hot! If you are using ABS, then you might be able to get away with 20 watts or higher. I have not tested with ABS, so this is just a conservative guess. Important: Please contact me if you wish to use this (or a direct derivative of this) lamp shade in a commercial environment, or if you are a contractor wanting to use these for residential contract. I couldn't get it to work properly and it's fairly clunky to put together and operate.   I'm not even sure if I have it put together correctly, because I don't know what the spring is for.   It seems like the "spring" that is the thin piece of plastic that sits over the ratchet is what keeps the thing working.  The spring from a pen or whatever seems to have the opposite effect of what you want.   It would have made more sense to have a spring above the ratchet pushing it down.  It's a pretty gun, but now it's just a paperweight.

description.text: I have a pair of bookshelves from Target that have handy metal tabs to secure them to a wall to prevent tipping. The baseboard and quarter round keep the shelf about 60mm from the wall. I designed this bracket to fit the tabs snugly and allow one screw to go through the tabs into the bracket. Another screw goes through the other hole in the bracket into a drywall anchor (or stud, if you're lucky).

I manually edited the g-code to slow down the perimeter to F800. This helped it stick to fresh blue tape on the HBP, without need for a raft. The holes print out great, no cleanup needed since the screw just takes care of any stray wisps leftover in the holes.

description.text:
This was a test article I designed for testing PET+ filament. I needed a thing which had a variety of challenging features so that I could test multiple situations at once given settings, but the thing had to print relatively quickly as it gets tiresome to wait and wait.
This thing has four posts of varying height, a very long bridge, and four 'holes'. The three things I try to test are infill success, stringing (between poles) and bridging.
So the Blue pictures are PET+ prints (MadeSolid filament) and the black ones are the standard Makerbot Black ABS material.

I designed this using TurboCAD 20, exported as STL.  
When you build it, pay close attention to the 'sag' in the bridge area, the 'ooze' coming off the columns (generally pointing toward the next column) and the finish on the tops of the columns/bridge. These things are parts of the challenge.

This thing is my first attempt at modeling. I don't have a printer yet, but my kit should be here any day now. I have not printed this thing. This thing is supposed to be a stackable spice rack for my kitchen. The compartments are sized to fit round spice bottles about 50mm in diameter. It is intended to hold the bottles lying down, with all of the lids facing front for easy spice identification. Edit 1/10/2013:
Crap. I think I made this thing bigger than the print bed on the Printrbot+. Edit 1/10/2013:
Revised the shape to fit in the 200mm X 200mm print bed of the Printrbot+. Tried to make hex2.stl modular/stackable. I am working on a few different shapes that actually lock together. Edit 1/11/2013:
Adding a few other shapes that should interlock together. Edit 2/18/2013:
Ok. I finally got my printer up and working. Tried printing a couple of the shapes. They slice fine, but take a rediculously long time to print, on the order of 6 to 8 hours. I think it is due partly to my infill settings and the small spaces between perimeters. Also found out that I didn't leave enough clearance around the interface areas between interlocking parts. They don't really fit together that well, or at all. I'll try adjusting the shapes when I have time.

The hinge connecting the head of my desk lamp to the arm broke, leaving the head dangling. I made a new one. It's not perfect (it's a little bit loose around the head, and the peg the hinge is on is too short), but it works.
Lamps get hot. I won't be responsible if your lamp melts this holder and burns your house down. You have been warned.

• Travel back in time to 2002.
  • Buy a Martha Stewart "Architect's Work Lamp".
  • Use it until the hinge breaks.
  • Print each part listed at the bottom of the OpenSCAD file (I used ABS).
  • Glue holder_top to the top of holder_bottom (I used ABS/acetone slurry).
  • Insert hinge_inside into the larger hole in hinge_outside from the bottom(without gluing).
  • Insert the square peg on holder_bottom into the hole in hinge_inside from the top (optionally gluing it).
  • Slide the holder over the head of the lamp, putting the power cable and the remnants of the old hinge through the gap opposite the new hinge.
  • Turn the holder so the old hinge remnant is trapped between holder_bottom and holder_top (see photo).
  • Remove the other side of the old hinge from the arm by removing the screw.
  • Insert the small hole in hinge_outside in the resulting gap, and replace the screw.

THIS IS MY OLD STAND. My new stand, the OmniStand, fits more filament spool sizes, and works for the right and left side of the FlashForge Dreamer. The OmniStand is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:652415 This modified FlashForge Dreamer spool holder includes a replacement stand, a detachable spool rod, and a spool rod cover that enlarges the rod's diameter. These are designed to replace the original stock black spool stand and rod that comes with the older FlashForge Dreamer versions. THIS SPOOL HOLDER IS INCOMPATIBLE WITH THE LATEST VERSION OF THE DREAMER (see photo 2). FlashForge changed the design. If you have the latest Dreamer with 2 cooling fans on the back, and a clear door, this spool holder will NOT fit that model without modifications. The newer printers have 2 posts that are in the way. I don't know the measurements of the 2 posts. I would like to modify this holder to work for both new and old printers. If anyone knows the measurements of the 2 new posts in relation to the 2 screw holes please post about it so that I can update the design to work for both new and older printers. Thanks. The rod is 8.5 mm longer than the stock black rod. The stand is 41.25 mm taller than the stock black stand. When attaching the new stand, you need to take off the Dreamer's bottom and unscrew the original stand from the bottom. Do not unscrew the stand from the top or the nut on the bottom will come lose and potentially get lost. Screw the original stand's screws into the new stand before attaching the new stand to the Dreamer using the original nuts. ONLY USE ON THE LEFT SIDE. See below. These use the same rod connection point so the rod is compatible with the original black spool stand. This new spool stand and rod allows you to use much larger filament spools. It can accommodate filament rolls as large as 200 mm in diameter by 56 mm wide. Tested filament rolls which fit this modified spool holder include:
  • MG Chemicals 0.25 kg
  • Filamex 0.5 kg
  • Ninjaflex 0.5 kg
  • ZenToolworks 1.0 kg
  • ASAPTech 1.0 kg
    • MG Chemicals 0.25 kg, and Filamex 0.5 kg filament rolls do not require the new stand, but do require the new filament rod. They do not fit the stock filament rod that ships with the Dreamer because it's not long enough. The rod cover piece makes the rod diameter a bit larger to match the outer diameter of the stand connection point. This piece is needed for some filament rolls to work properly. For example, ZenToolworks 1.0 kg rolls require this rod cover to operate properly, while FlashForge rolls work without the cover attached.. NOTE: THIS IS FOR THE LEFT SIDE ONLY. The Dreamer has filament holders on the right and left side. Installing this spool holder on the right side is not recommended because it can cause the filament spool to touch the Y axis stepper motor. I am looking into this problem.
Print the filament rod standing upright. Print the filament stand on it's side so that the rod hole is facing up. Print the rod cover standing upright.

comments.author: fwkohler

comments.text: I use Simplify3D to slice the models. I make sure there's no less than 50% infill in most places, and near the locking area of the rod I make it 100% infill to prevent the pieces from breaking. Simplify3D allows different infill settings for different parts of a printed model. Most slicers don't offer that. If that's not available, I would print the rod with no less than 50% infill.

comments.text: Thank you for the detailed reply, Mr. Williams. I can specify support on FlashPrint now and the slicer works well, surprisingly. I am using PVA and HIPS as support for complicated support structure. I am not using S3D at the moment because it doesn't have trial versions but use Kisslicer which is very good. However, I can't use it for support prints because I haven't configured it well enough - even though both extruders are selected on startup, the extruder that is not being used at the time tends to cool down until actual printing. The constant cooling and heating of both extruders frequently has made the print job practically unuseable for Kisslicer. I note that FlashPrint doesn't have that problem - both extruders are heated to temperature and they stayed there even with extruder changes. It is obviously something that I haven't taken into account on configuration. I use the following g-codes.

author: thegabbler

description.text: This is a Stepper Motor mount I designed to mount the stepper Motor for the Extruder to the ground plate of my printer. Used Hot Glue to mount it, but also M3 Screws can be used.
I don't even. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eRdMHuiKqqh

This Parts allow to move the extruder from the Print Head away to somewere else, to reduce the weight of the printhead. This has greatly improved print quallity on fast direction changes of the printer.

This consists of 3 Parts.
  • The Replacement Part for the Extruder on the print head
  • The Mount for the tubing on the extruder of the printerbot
  • Optional: A mount for a 40mm fan that keeps the upper part of the hot-end cool. This is optional, works perfectly (tested on 8 hour print) without it.
    Used a spare pressured-air tubing to connect the extruder to the hotend.
    You will have to drill up the whole a little bit. Used M3 Screws and Nuts to lock everything in place.
    Note: I had to oil the inner side of the tubing as otherwise the friction was too much for the motor.

comments.text: How well does this perform? And what software did you use?
comments.author: PurifiedSoap

comments.text: Having no issues with it. Removes a lot of weight from the hotend, so better print quality in my opinion. Using Marlin.
comments.author: PurifiedSoap

comments.text: This seems to be a very interesting concept. Is it possible to provide a bigger picture that shows both extruder and hot end at the same time? I'm wondering about the flexibility and length of the tubing. One drawback of this design is the extra filament between the extruder and hot end. Every time you need to change filament, you have to pull all the way back. Same goes with the jams. It may be harder to clear the jams. However, I  see the improvement over the stability and precision.
comments.author: obben

description.text:
Hash sign. #  
Original design by Sdsyc
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

This Base Plate is a must have for every MakerBot Digitizer user.
The Digitizer can produce excellent scans using the Multiscan feature. However the single biggest problem users face is repositioning the object being scanned for additional Multiscans (to add additional detail) so they are stable enough to do additional scans.
This Base Plate is the solution. Print the plate in "MakerBot True Green PLA" and use the pins to support the item being scanned, reorient / reposition it and carry out the necessary number of Multiscans to capture the additional detail required.
This makes holding objects being scanned easy and allows users to take full advantage of the Multiscan function.
It is essential to print this in MakerBot True Green PLA.
THE SECRET: Most people have heard about the use of 'green screens' for movie and TV visual effect. The same principal applies with the Digitizer... the strong mid green colour is not picked up by the lasers. This means your scans will appear to scan in mid air!
Whatever you scan can be supported by this base plate and the pins (push through from underneath) and repositioned / reoriented to suit and they will not appear in scans. Refer to the images provided.
NB: If they do appear slightly then scan at a lower setting (Light). REFER TO INSTRUCTIONS FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

MUST be printed with MakerBot True Green PLA so the Base Plate and Pins do not show up in scans
Locate the Base Plate lugs into the two holes in the Digitizer turntable.
Push the Pins of the necessary length through the Base Plate at the appropriate positions to support the object to be scanned in the desired orientation.
TIPS: Success with the Digitizer also relies on controlling lighting conditions. If scans are picking up a lot of 'noise' then cover the Digitizer and scan in the dark using the 'light' setting. This eliminates nearby light sources affecting scans (Refer image provided).
Scanning objects with shiny or reflective surfaces causes problems. Overcome this by painting the object with water colour white or light gray water based (poster) matt paint. It will make it easier to scan and wash off cleanly afterwards.

description.text:
Deer ate the carrot nose off of our snowman. My over-tired 4-year old son was very upset and my wife said "your Dad will print you a new one that the deer won't eat," and he calmed down. A quick search of Thingiverse revealed that I would have to model my own.
I did so very quickly and it's not my best, but here it is. Ready to print and be installed on a snowman near you.
Scale in accordance with your snowman.  Print in orange.  Make sure your printer slows down for the uppermost layers so they have time to cool.

I created this using Autodesk 123D Catch. It came out pretty good for the most part, not perfect. It took me 15 minutes to create this including taking pictures and processing. This is a semi-low polygon model, I might make a higher resolution version when I get the chance. Feel free to do whatever with it, just remember to give credit and don't use it for commercial purposes or financial gain.

title: Futuristic: a Car and a Transportation System

description.text:
Hi, everyone. I am a Industrial design student from China. This is my envision of the future personal transportation system.
At the core of this system is a car with two seats. It is two-wheeled and balanced by gyroscope and microcomputers on board. This design can greatly reduce turning mechanics and increase its agility.
Through the center under the car there is a slot. This slot serves as a positioning tool when the car gets on another platform. The car itself serves best as a regional, local transportation method. When you want to make a longer trip, you can drive the car directly to the train station. Buy a ticket through on board computer and then drive onto the train. You car will automatically fasten itself to the train and rotate forward. That's really easy!!
Thanks for visiting my project. Please feel free to tell me any idea you have in mind, I am happy to talk about it.

This makes a low vacuum extractor at the side of a solidoodle 2 case to get rid of the ABS fumes. It adapts to an 80mm fan. I assume it can be used for other tasks.

Print this on your favorite 3d printer. Attach it to an 80mm fan with 4 (or two? or three?) 4-40x1/2" screws. Hang it on the lower back right corner of the solidoodle case by inserting a wood screw into the hole in the adapter (so the screw head pinches the edge of the frame) and running a bead of hot glue along the back corner of the solidoodle case to give the lip of the adapter something to catch on. Also print the "tube adapter for 80mm fan" to send the air from the fan into a shop vac hose.
This has been designed to work when the solidoodle frame is mostly enclosed, i.e. by some clear plastic curtains or similar. A rather weak fan is best, because you don't want to over-cool the printer with too much air flow.

comments.text:
hi,
I am building my second CNC and our designs are about the same exept from the Z axis, where I have stable bearings and moving shafts instead and the frame is made from 60x30x3 steel tubes (by the way, the cost of my frame is less than 100 euros but you need to have a welding machine, a cutter saw and a drill press to handle steel properly)
I have not finished it yet but I noticed that there is some flex in the Y axis because of the length of the shafts (mine are 75cm). Please share your experience on this area.
I addition, I have not yet decide what spindle to buy. I am thinking for Kress 1050 as well but I have some concerns about its runout. As I am going to use it for milling mostly abs enclosures and pcbs, do you have any experience on this area, pcbs mainly? Is it going to be a problem for milling pcbs with 8 mil traces for smds?
My current experience is with Dremel 3000 and its runout is a lot probably about 0.3 - 0.4 mm and it is really bad for pcbs unless I aim for 24mill traces.
comments.author: tcop

comments.text:
Hi. I have not had eny problems with flex in the y-axis on this machine. The shafts are 20mm in diameter and the bed is made of MDF, so there is barely any weight on the shafts. The machine was not built for milling heavy elements, so I have not experienced any flex in the y-axis. You must have a heavy bed or small diameter shafts? An alternative could be to use supported shafts. I have done that before on another machine. That will definitely solve your problems.
About the kress: If i remember correct there was a document with my new kress fme 850 that verified a runout of less than 0.05mm or something like that. I have not routed pcb's with the machine, so I can't say if the runout would be sufficiently small to deliver a good result when routing pcb's with only 8 mil traces. But it is without doubt far more precise than a dremel.
comments.author: tcop

comments.text:
my bed is wooden, at least for now. I notice the flex when i press the bed with my hands. I suppose i am forcing it at about 15-20kg. It is not the bed weight that concerns me but the z axis vertical movement-force that is apllied on the bed. In my first cnc I noticed that a nema 17 stepper of the Z, coupled with an 8 mm rod (1.25mm step/turn), could apply on the tip of my milling bit so much force that the 12mm rods on the bed where curving like bananas. That happend a few times when I forgot to switch on the dremel before beggining milling but this was the main reason I bought 20mm shafts now. Anyway, I 'll see how it goes.
By the way, what is your max speed?
comments.author: nic6911

comments.text: I would not allow my z-axis to apply that much force. I guess it would damage my spindle if it was running and forced with 20kg. So if you run your machine without forgetting to turn on the spindle my guess is that you will not experience any problems :-)

title: 80mm fan to dryer vent adapter for FlashForge Dreamer

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1k7NXermR0R 80mm fan to dryer vent adapter for FlashForge Dreamer to vent the ABS fumes.

comments.text: Great addition to the Dreamer printer.  Too bad so many folks don't understand the dangers of ABS plastic...
comments.author: Narg

comments.text: My first print got me my first ABS headache. This was the best solution though you won't want the fan to move to much air as it can cool the Dreamer down too much for ABS.

author: rustutzman

title: Golden Gate Of Freiberg Cathedral Statue 3D Scan

description.text:
This is a 3D scan (Artec MH) of a statue from the Golden Gate of Freiberg Cathedral.
It is a sample scan from Artec but it wasn't solid and printable so I edited it. I used Artec Studio and MeshMixer (http://www.meshmixer.com) to fill holes, delete parts and smooth the model.
The original model is here:
http://www.artec3d.com/tag/?tags=Artec+MH||Virtual+Museum http://www.3dwp.nl

comments.text: Wow, that's an excellent scan!
comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text: I thought so, too! It's not scanned by me but I have the same scanner, the Artec MH. It took some work but the statue is now printable like it should .
comments.author: MustangDave
